metadata.title: Large-scale high-efficiency dye-sensitized solar cells based on a Pt/carbon spheres composite catalyst as a flexible counter electrode

(c) Arrhenius plots of the charge transfer resistance; (d) Arrhenius plots of the exchange current density (J 0). Fig. 6 Current density–voltage (J–V) curves of the DSCs using flexible CS, Pt, and Pt/CS CEs. Fig. 7 (a) Photograph of the flexible large-scale Pt/CS electrode. (b) J–V curves of the large-scale DSCs using flexible Pt and Pt/CS CEs: (▴, ●) the DSCs using photoanodes on a rigid FTO glass substrate; (■, ★) the DSCs using photoanodes on a flexible ITO-PEN substrate. CE catalysts R s/Ωcm2 R ct/Ωcm2 Z N/Ωcm2 J 0/mAcm−2 a J 0/mAcm−2 b E a/kJmol−1 c CS 34.18 4.77 27.12 5.21 5.79 37.03 Pt 33.57 3.14 22.31 7.91 8.39 34.25 Pt/CS 32.52 2.09 17.64 12.12 13.84 26.55 a Exchange current density (J 0) values calculated through EIS tests. b J 0 values calculated through Tafel curve tests. c Apparent activation energy calculated through the Arrhenius plot (Fig. 5d). Large-scale high-efficiency dye-sensitized solar cells based on a Pt/carbon spheres composite catalyst as a flexible counter electrode Yajing Zhu Chenjing Gao Qianji Han Zhuo Wang Yanru Wang Haikuo Zheng Mingxing Wu ⁎ College of Chemistry and Material Science, Key Laboratory of Inorganic Nanomaterials of Hebei Province, Hebei Normal University, No. 20 Rd. East of 2nd Ring South, Yuhua District, Shijiazhuang City, Hebei Province 050024, China College of Chemistry and Material Science Key Laboratory of Inorganic Nanomaterials of Hebei Province Hebei Normal University No. 20 Rd. East of 2nd Ring South Yuhua District Shijiazhuang City Hebei Province 050024 China ⁎ Corresponding author. Graphical abstract A composite (Pt/CS) catalyst produced by homogeneously depositing Pt nanoparticles on a carbon spheres (CS) surface is synthesized by a simple method. A large-scale, highly effective, and flexible counter electrode is further fabricated with this composite catalyst on an ITO-PEN substrate for dye-sensitized solar cells (DSCs). As inferred from cyclic voltammetry, electrochemical impedance spectroscopy, and Tafel polarization curves results, this flexible Pt/CS counter electrode exhibits higher catalytic activity toward Co3+/2+ redox couple regeneration than Pt and CS counter electrodes. The supercatalytic behavior of Pt/CS can essentially be attributed to the low apparent activation energy (E a) of the redox reaction between Co3+ and Co2+. Using the Pt/CS counter electrode, a high power conversion efficiency (PCE) of 9.02% is achieved with a small DSCs (16mm2), and the largescale device (360mm2) generates a PCE of 6.26% under 100mWcm−2 of simulated sunlight illumination. Keywords Solar cells Pt/carbon sphere Flexible Counter electrode Composite 1 Introduction Dye-sensitized solar cells (DSCs) are biphasic systems in which a photoanode, usually composed of a mesoporous semiconductor sensitized by a matched charge-transfer dye, is in contact with an electrolyte containing a redox couple acting as electron mediators to allow hole transfer to a counter electrode (CE) [1]. The redox couple regeneration occurs in the CE surface, which serves as a catalyst. I3 −/I− is a widely used redox couple, whose application remains the highlight of current DSCs industrialization efforts. However, the problems of corrosivity and volatility and huge overpotential loss of dye regeneration have limited cells efficiency and commercial application of the I3 −/I− electrolyte-based photovoltaic device. The development of candidates to replace I3 −/I− electrolyte has become a research hotspot, which could provide more stable and efficient modules, e.g., redox couples of Fe3+/2+ [2,3], Cu2+/+ [4,5], Ni4+/3+ [6,7], V5+/4+ [8], and Mn1+/0 [9]-based metal complex as well as entirely organic couples of TEMPO1+/0 (2,2,6,6-tetramethyl-1-piperidinyloxy) [10], hydroquinone/benzoquinone [11], disulfide/thiolate (T2/T−) and its derivatives [12–15], which have already demonstrated their potentialities as possible alternatives to I3 −/I− when conjunct with specific dye architectures. The reader can obtain useful information concerning redox couples and CEs from the latest review paper [16]. In contrast to the aforementioned redox couples, cobalt complexes (Co3+/2+)-based electrolytes boast the advantages of lower extinction coefficients in the visible light region, weak absorption competition with the sensitizers, and readily tunable redox potentials, which lead to concomitant outstanding solubility, stability, and absorbance. The Grätzel group assembled DSCs using the Co3+/2+ redox couple combined with hindered push–pull sensitizers and Pt CE, which showed high power conversion efficiency (PCE) values of 12.3 and 13.0% [17,18]. These results indicate that Pt is an ideal CE catalyst to reduce Co3+ to Co2+ without regard to commercial application. However, Pt is an expensive and rare noble metal; exploring low-cost catalysts to replace Pt could decrease the fabrication cost of DSCs and improve the commercial competitiveness of Co3+/2+ redox couple-based DSCs. Fortunately, several low-cost Pt-free CE catalysts have been applied in the Co3+/2+ redox system: polymers, oxides, carbides, sulfide, selenides, carbon materials, etc. [19–27]. Among these Pt-free materials, the carbon materials are the most promising candidates due to their inherent advantages of low cost and high catalytic activity in commercial application of DSCs. Previous work has proved that carbon electrodes perform better toward the cobalt redox couple than Pt [28,29]. Recently, we also found that carbon spheres (CS) was effective in DSCs system in terms of redox couple regeneration, while DSCs using a CS CE still exhibited lower photovoltaic performance than the Pt CE-based device [30]. Hence, CS should be a potential candidate to replace Pt if its catalytic activity can be enhanced effectually. Moreover, it remains unclear whether CS offer a tangible advantage at least in terms of cell efficiency or not, compared with Pt CE. In previous reports, design carbon-materials-supported Pt composite catalysts, such as Pt/carbon fiber, Pt/carbon black, and Pt/CNTs, is a feasible path to improve catalytic activity and to cut Pt consumption [31–33]. In this work, we try to synthesize a Pt/CS composite catalyst for use in cobalt redox electrolyte-based DSCs. On one hand, this Pt/CS composite can reduce the amount of Pt as well as the cost of the DSCs. On the other hand, design composites can remarkably enhance the catalytic activity of CE. We characterized the surface morphology, inner structure, and crystallinity of Pt/CS by means of transmission electron microscopy (TEM), scanning electron microscopy (SEM), X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS), X-ray diffraction (XRD), and N2 adsorption–desorption isotherms. The electrochemical behavior of Pt/CS toward the cobalt redox couple was evaluated by cyclic voltammetry (CV), electrochemical impedance spectroscopy (EIS), and Tafel polarization curves. Furthermore, calculation of the apparent activation energy of the redox reaction between Co3+ and Co2+ was considered in an effort to elucidate the basic mechanism for the high catalytic activity of the composite Pt/CS electrode. Finally, we fabricated large-scale flexible CEs using Pt, CS, and Pt/CS and characterized the photovoltaic performances of DSCs using these CEs. 2 Experimental 2.1 Preparation of CS and Pt/CS electrodes The carbon spheres was prepared as described in previous work [34]. The Pt/CS composite is prepared as follows: Add 200mgCS to 10mL isopropanol solution containing chloroplatinic acid (0.05, 0.10, 0.15, or 0.20wt.%). In an open system, let the isopropanol solvent vaporize under stir to make the chloroplatinic acid absorb on the CS surface, and collect the CS that have absorbed chloroplatinic acid. Then sinter the CS absorbed chloroplatinic acid under N2 at 450°C for 30min, and the Pt/CS is obtained. We can calculate that the Pt/CS electrodes contained 0.7, 1.4, 2.1, or 2.8wt.% of Pt. The CS or Pt/CS electrodes are prepared as follows: Add 100mg CS (or Pt/CS) to 5mL isopropanol, ultrasonically disperse them for 30min, and the CS (or Pt/CS) suspension is achieved. The prepared suspension is then sprayed onto a flexible indium-doped tin oxide coated polyethylene naphthalate (ITO-PEN) substrate. In this step, the carrier gas is air, spray pressure is set at 0.2MPa, and the distance from the spray equipment to the ITO-PEN substrate is controlled at 8cm. Subsequently, the ITO-PEN coated with CS (or Pt/CS) film is sintered under N2 at 100°C for 10min and the CS or Pt/CS electrodes are achieved. 2.2 Assembly of DSCs For preparation of a rigid photoanode, precleaned FTO glass was immersed into a 40mM aqueous TiCl4 solution for 20min, washed with distilled water, and sintered at 500°C for 30min to form a blocking layer. The FTO glass with blocking layer was further coated with a 6.0μm thick second layer of TiO2 nanoparticles, followed by sintering at 500°C for 30min to obtain a mesoporous TiO2 film. The prepared 6μm thick TiO2 film was preheated to 80°C and immersed in a 2×10−4 M solution of YD2-o-C8 dye in ethanol for 20h, and a rigid photoanode was achieved. The flexible photoanodes are prepared as follows: A dilute TiO2 paste was sprayed on ITO-PEN substrate to form a TiO2 film around 6μm thick. Then the ITO-PEN coated with TiO2 film was sintered at 120°C for 20min. The prepared 6μm thick TiO2 film on ITO-PEN substrate was preheated to 80°C and immersed in a 2×10−4 M solution of YD2-o-C8 dye in ethanol for 20h and a flexible photoanode was achieved. The cobalt electrolyte is composed of 0.25M Co (II) tris (bipyridyl) tetracyanoborate, 0.05M Co (III) tris (bipyridyl) tetracyanoborate, 0.5M TBP, and 0.1M LiTFSI in acetonitrile. The DSCs consist of a photoanode, a CE, and an electrolyte, and the active area of the device is 0.25cm2. The symmetrical cell is fabricated with two identical electrodes clipping the electrolyte for EIS and Tafel polarization tests. 2.3 Measurements XRD measurements were carried out using an automatic X-ray powder diffractometer (D8 advance, Bruker Corporation). XPS measurement was conducted with an XPS spectrometer(ESCALAB250, Thermo, USA). The morphologies of CS and Pt/CS were characterized by scanning Electron microscopy (SEM, S-4800, Hitachi, Japan) and transmission electron microscopy (TEM, H-7650, Hitachi, Japan; Tecnai G2 F30 S-TWIN, FEI, USA). N2 adsorption–desorption experiments were undertaken isothermally at 77K on a NOVA4000e automated surface area analyzer (Quantachrome, USA), and the surface area was calculated by the Brunauer–Emmett–Teller (BET) method. EIS experiments were performed using symmetrical cells with an electrochemical workstation system (CHI 660E, Chenhua, Shanghai) at −20, −10, 0, and 15°C. The measured frequency ranged from 100mHz to 1MHz. The amplitude of the alternating current was set at 5mV. Tafel polarization curve measurements were carried out with an electrochemical workstation system in a symmetrical dummy cell. The scan rate was 10mVs−1. CV measurements were carried out in a three-electrode system in an argon-purged electrolyte solution at a scan rate of 20mVs−1 using an electrochemical workstation system. Pt wire served as the counter electrode and Ag/Ag+ as the reference electrode. The Co3+/2+ electrolyte is composed of 0.01M Co2+, 0.001M Co3+, and 0.1M LiClO4 in acetonitrile. The current density–voltage curves of the DSCs were investigated under simulated AM 1.5 illumination (I =100mWcm−2, PEC-L01, Peccell, Yokohama, Japan). 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Synthesis and characterization of materials As is commonly known, CS is a high-performing functional material owing to their uniformity, high thermal stability, high surface-to-volume ratios, and excellent conductivity, indicating considerable application potential as adsorbents, catalysts, fuel cells, drug delivery systems, nano devices, and lithium ion battery materials [34–37]. Recently, we have found that CS is a promising CE catalyst for iodide and cobalt redox couples in DSCs system [30,38]. However, the catalytic activity of the CS is still lower than that of Pt, and should be enhanced if the CS is to be a qualified CE catalyst. Pt is a qualified CE catalyst for the Co3+/2+ redox couple regardless of its cost. Here we try to deposit Pt nanoparticles onto CS supports and generate a composite Pt/CS catalyst, to reduce the usage of Pt and enhance the catalytic activity of CS. Fig. S1 in the Supporting Information is the XRD patterns of the synthesized CS and Pt/CS. With regard to CS, the peak at 43.00° refers to the (101) diffraction plane of hexagonal graphitic carbon. In Pt/CS, the diffraction peaks at 40.16°, 46.60°, and 67.86° can be assigned to the crystal planes (111), (200), and (220) respectively, for Pt (No. 65-2868, PDF-2 database). The weak diffraction peak of CS at 43.00° may be overlapped by the sharp diffraction peaks of Pt at 40.16° and 46.60°. Fig. 1 is the SEM images of the CS and their precursors, which demonstrate a typical spherical shape. The TEM images in Fig. 2 a and b indicate that CS and their precursors maintain solid spherical structures with diameters 150–200nm and 200–250nm, respectively. In Fig. 1c, it can be observed that Pt/CS presents a honeycomb texture due to the possible corrosion effect generated by chloroplatinic acid. Moreover, Pt nanoparticles are embedded in the honeycomb lattices on the Pt/CS surface. The HR-TEM images in Fig. 2c–e confirm that Pt/CS has been synthesized successfully, with Pt nanoparticle inlay in the CS surface and the diameter of the Pt nanoparticle around 5nm, as shown in Fig. 2f. The interplanar spacing of 0.23nm refers to the Pt (111) crystal face. Furthermore, energy-dispersive X-ray spectroscopy (EDS) was carried out to confirm the formation of Pt/CS. According to the EDS image in Fig. 1d, a certain amount of Pt can be observed. In addition, in order to evaluate the surface information of the prepared Pt/CS, XPS was carried out. In Fig. 3 a, the peaks at 70.0 and 282.7eV, which correspond to the binding energy of Pt4f and C1s, suggest the presence of Pt and carbon. Fig. 3b displays a close-up of the fitted XPS spectra of Pt4f, which is split into two peaks at 69.1 and 73.1eV corresponding to Pt4f7/2 and Pt4f5/2, respectively. All of the XRD, EDS, and XPS results show that Pt/CS has been synthesized. To examine the internal structures of the CS and Pt/CS, N2 adsorption–desorption isotherms were determined. As shown in Fig. 3c and d, the two samples both exhibit a typical IV pattern, implying a mesoporous structure [39]. Moreover, the hysteresis loop for the capillary condensation of N2 inside the pores generally demonstrates a mesoporous structure. As the inset shows in Fig. 3c, the pore sizes of CS distribute at 3.3 and 5.1nm. As for Pt/CS, besides 3.3 and 5.1nm, a pore size of 8.3nm is found, which may be associated with the honeycomb structure. The BET surface area of CS is 417.1m2 g−1, while the surface area of Pt/CS rises to 470.0m2 g−1. 3.2 Catalytic properties of the prepared CS and Pt/CS toward the Co3+/2+ redox couple CV is an effective tool for evaluating catalytic activity in previous research [40], which has been carried out with CS, Pt, and Pt/CS as work electrodes. In Fig. 4 a, one pair of redox peaks is observed in all three electrodes, which is related to the redox reaction between Co3+ and Co2+. In this regard, the CV profile of CS is similar to that of Pt, indicating a similar catalytic mechanism for cobalt redox couple regeneration. The differences of CS from Pt include lower peak current density (i p) and higher peak-to-peak separation (ΔE P), displaying relatively lower catalytic activity of CS according to previous reports that ΔE P varies inversely with charge transfer rate (ks) [38,41]. When Pt nanoparticles were deposited into CS, the Pt/CS exhibits a positive cathodic peak and a negative anodic peak, resulting in a lower ΔE P than those for Pt and CS. In addition, compared with Pt and CS, the current densities are also improved significantly for the composite Pt/CS. According to the CV results, we can deduce that Pt/CS is more effective than CS and Pt in catalyzing the regeneration of the cobalt redox couple. Furthermore, Fig. 4b shows the cyclic voltammograms at various scan rates. The current density increases with the increase of scan rate. Also, Fig. 4c shows the relationship between the peak current density and the square root of the scan rate, and the linear relation is in good agreement with the equation (1) i p = 2.69 × 10 5 n 3 2 AD 1 2 V 1 2 C , where i p is the peak current density, n is the number of electrons transferred, A is the area of the electrode, D is the diffusion coefficient, V is the scan rate, and C is the concentration. With the increase of the scan rate, the diffusion layer becomes thinner and the electrochemical polarization becomes higher, which leads to high overpotential and poor reversibility. This phenomenon has also been observed in earlier research [42,43]. The linear relationship indicates that the diffusion properties of the cobalt species on the Pt/CS electrode surface may exert a huge influence on the catalytic process [44]. Moreover, Fig. 4d indicates that, after 20 cycles of cyclic voltammetry scan, no current density decline or peak shifts are observed in the Pt/CS electrode, which implies that great stability and Pt/CS can coexist with cobalt redox species for a long time. The CV results show that the Pt/CS is a promising catalyst for the cobalt redox couple and is expected to perform well in the photovoltaic devices. To investigate the electrochemical process of Pt/CS, which has a close relationship to the catalytic activity, EIS was carried out at 15°C using symmetrical cells fabricated with two identical electrodes. Typical Nyquist plots are shown in Fig. 5 a. The high-frequency intercept on the real axis corresponds to the series resistance (R s). The left semicircle refers to the charge transfer at the electrode/electrolyte interface, from which the charge transfer resistance (R ct) can be derived; the right semicircle refers to the diffusion impedance (Z N) caused by ion diffusion through the bulk Co3+/2+ electrolyte. The values of the EIS parameters are obtained by fitting the EIS plots with an equivalent circuit (inset in Fig. 5a). The corresponding EIS parameters are summarized in Table 1 . The R s values of CS, Pt, and Pt/CS can be considered to be of the same order of magnitude. The R ct values of the CS and Pt are 4.77 and 3.14Ωcm2, respectively. In contrast, the R ct value of Pt/CS is reduced to 2.09Ωcm2. This indicates a high charge transfer velocity at the Pt/CS electrode|electrolyte interface. Therefore, Co3+ can be reduced smoothly to Co2+ on the Pt/CS electrode surface. Moreover, the Z N value of the Pt/CS is lower than those of the CS and Pt, indicating a high diffusion velocity of the redox couples [45]. According to the EIS results, Pt/CS behaves more effectively than CS or Pt in cobalt redox couple regeneration. The catalytic behavior order of CS, Pt, and Pt/CS is attributed to the different R ct and Z N. Tafel polarization measurements were also carried out to reconfirm the catalytic activity of the Pt/CS electrodes. Fig. 5b shows the Tafel polarization curves of the symmetrical cells, which are similar to the ones used in EIS measurements. The curves present logarithmic current density (J) as a function of voltage (U); the detailed Tafel polarization analysis can be found in previous research [46]. In detail, the exchange current density (J 0) of the CS is 5.79mAcm2, which is lower than that of Pt (8.39mAcm2). This indicates that CS has relatively lower catalytic activity than Pt. However, the curve of Pt/CS indicates a higher J 0 (13.84mAcm2) compared with those of CS and Pt, demonstrating that Pt/CS performs better than CS and Pt. Theoretically, J 0 varies inversely with R ct, and the change tendency of J 0 that is deduced from the EIS results is generally in accordance with those presented in the Tafel curves. Based on the R ct values in the EIS results, the J 0 values can be calculated according to the equation (2) j 0 = RT / nFR ct , where R is the gas constant, T is the temperature, F is Faraday’s constant, n is the electron number involved in the reaction, and R ct and J0 have the usual meaning, as 5.21 (CS), 7.91 (Pt) and 12.12mAcm−2 (Pt/CS). After performing a comprehensive analysis of the CV, EIS, and Tafel polarization measurement results, we contend that the Pt/CS exhibits stronger catalytic behavior than Pt and CS toward the cobalt redox couple. To obtain more specific information about the kinetics of the charge transfer reaction, EIS measurements have been conducted at different temperatures of −20, −10, 0, and 15°C. The Nyquist plots are listed in the Supplementary Information (Figs. S2–S4). The EIS parameters are summarized in Tables 1 and S1. Fig. 5c describes the R ct values as a function of the inverse of the absolute temperature. As is discussed above, according to the R ct values at different temperatures, the J 0 values can be calculated by virtue of Eq. (2). As a result, we draw Fig. 5d, which describes the J 0 values as a function of the inverse of the absolute temperature. J 0 is an important parameter in the description of the kinetics of the charge transfer reaction at the electrode/electrolyte interface. The exchange current density follows the equation [47] (3) j 0 = J inf e - E a / RT , where J inf is the exchange current density at infinite temperature and E a is the apparent activation energy. Based on Eq. (3), the temperature-dependent measurements enable the calculation of E a in the electron transfer process of the cobalt redox couple at different counter electrode interfaces (Table 1). Pt is an ideal catalyst for Co3+/2+, and the calculated E a value is 34.25kJmol−1. In contrast, the E a value of CS is 37.03kJmol−1, implying that the redox reaction of Co3+/2+ consumes more energy on CS electrodes than on Pt electrodes. As for Pt/CS, the E a value declined to 26.55kJmol−1. Obviously, Pt/CS exhibits higher catalytic activity than CS and Pt. In other words, the Co3+/2+ redox reaction on Pt/CS electrodes consumes the least energy to overcome E a with respect to thermodynamics. Moreover, in terms of reaction kinetics, a lower E a indicates a higher reaction rate (k) according to the equation (4) k = Ae - E a / RT , where k is the reaction rate and A is a pre-exponential factor related to the activation entropy. In summary, a lower E a means a higher catalytic activity of Pt/CS from the perspectives of both thermodynamics and kinetics. 3.3 Application of the prepared CS and Pt/CS in DSCs We fabricated DSCs using flexible CS, Pt, and Pt/CS CEs, Co3+/2+ as redox couple in the electrolyte, and zinc–porphyrin dye as sensitizer (YD2-o-C8). Fig. 6 is the current density–voltage (J–V) curves of the DSCs, and the photovoltaic parameters are summarized in Table S2 in the Supporting Information. The device using the CS CE shows a PCE of 6.70%, with open-circuit voltage (V oc) of 846mV, short-circuit current density (J sc) of 12.18mAcm−2, and fill factor (FF) of 0.65, which are lower than those of the DSCs using the Pt CE (8.42%). When the CE is changed from CS to Pt/CS, the PCE value rises to 9.05%, which is much higher than the DSCs using CS CE, and rivals the Pt-based device. The enhanced photovoltaic performance of the Pt/CS-based device can be ascribed to the improved J sc (14.24mAcm−2) and FF (0.74), reflecting the high catalytic activity of the Pt/CS toward the cobalt redox couple, and the high FF can be ascribed to the combined actions of the lower R s, R ct, and Z N properties. In this work, to evaluate the impact of Pt loading amount on the catalytic activity, we prepared four kinds of Pt/CS electrodes that contained 0.7, 1.4, 2.1, and 2.8wt.% Pt, which were denoted as Pt/CS-1, Pt/CS-2, Pt/CS-3, and Pt/CS-4. The J–V curves of the DSCs using the four kinds of Pt/CS CE with different Pt loadings are shown in Fig. S5 and the photovoltaic performance is listed in Table S3 in the Supporting Information. From Pt/CS-1 to -4, the DSCs exhibited PCE values of 7.39, 8.40, 9.05, and 8.90%. Obviously, the Pt/CS-3 with 2.1wt.% Pt loading exhibited the highest catalytic activity, while a continuous increase of Pt loading did not enhance the catalytic activity. Therefore, preparation of the composite can be regarded as an effective method to obtain a highly effective catalyst. Furthermore, the Pt/CS composite CE can greatly reduce the required Pt dosage, thereby reducing the cost of DSC without sacrificing PCE. The above experimental results prove the potential of Pt/CS for lab use to enhance the PCE and reduce the fabrication cost. The active area of the lab DSCs is only 16mm2. The device scale must be enlarged for industrial application. In this work, we prepared a large-scale Pt/CS electrode with area 500mm2. Fig. 7 a shows a photograph of the large-scale Pt/CS electrode on a flexible ITO-PEN substrate. We fabricated DSCs using the large-scale Pt/CS CE, which is combined with a rigid photoanode on FTO glass and a flexible photoanode on ITO-PEN substrate, respectively. The dimensions of the DSCs is 8×45mm, and the active area of the DSCs is 360mm2, which is determined by the photoanode. Fig. 7b is the J–V curves of the large-scale DSCs using Pt and Pt/CS CEs, and the photovoltaic parameters are listed in Table S4 in the Supporting Information. The rigid-photoanode-based DSCs using Pt/CS CE achieves a PCE of 6.26%, with V oc of 836mV, J sc of 12.27mAcm−2, and FF of 0.61, which is higher than the DSCs using the Pt CE (5.38%). In contrast, the flexible-photoanode-based DSCs using Pt/CS CE has a PCE of 3.94%, with V oc of 805mV, J sc of 9.23mAcm−2, and FF of 0.53, which are also higher than those of the Pt-based DSCs (3.23%). Obviously, the Pt/CS behaves better than Pt in both rigid- and flexible-photoanode-based DSCs. However, the large-scale DSCs exhibits a lower PCE than the small DSCs due to the great charge diffusion length in the large-scale device, resulting in a serious back reaction. The lower performance of the flexible-photoanode-based DSCs can be ascribed to two possible reasons: (1) the lack of a mesoporous network of the TiO2 film as a result of ITO-PEN failing to endure high temperature; (2) the ITO-PEN film not being as smooth as FTO glass, which can easily lead to a partial short circuit of the device in the encapsulation process, and even serious charge recombination and current leakage. Therefore, the flexible-photoanode-based DSCs yielded a low PCE with low V oc and J sc. 4 Conclusions Pt/CS composite electrodes were prepared through an in situ chemical method to reduce the quantity of Pt as well as to improve the catalytic activity in the DSCs system. A 2.1wt.% Pt loading is enough for the Pt/CS composite to achieve remarkable performance that is higher than CS and Pt. The DSCs using the Pt/CS composite CE yielded a high PCE of 9.05%, surpassing those of the CS- and Pt-based DSCs (6.70%, 8.42%). In addition, the enhanced performance of the DSCs can be attributed to the improved catalytic activity of the Pt/CS CE, evidenced by the low apparent activation energy of the cobalt redox couple regeneration. In the large-scale DSCs, Pt/CS likewise exhibited high catalytic activity, and the device generated a PCE of 6.28%, which was better than the performance of the DSCs using the Pt CE (5.38%). To sum up, preparation of economical composite CEs is a feasible way to reduce the cost of DSCs as well as to enhance the PCE of the DSCs. Acknowledgments The project was supported by the Science Foundation of Hebei Normal University (L2016J02), the National Natural Science Foundation of China (21303039), the Natural Science Foundation of Hebei Province (B2015205163, B2013205171), the Second Batch of Young Talent of Hebei Province, and the Support Program for Hundred Excellent Innovation Talents from the Universities of Hebei Province (BR2-220). coredata.dc:description: A composite (Pt/CS) catalyst produced by homogeneously depositing Pt nanoparticles on a carbon spheres (CS) surface is synthesized by a simple method. A large-scale, highly effective, and flexible counter electrode is further fabricated with this composite catalyst on an ITO-PEN substrate for dye-sensitized solar cells (DSCs). As inferred from cyclic voltammetry, electrochemical impedance spectroscopy, and Tafel polarization curves results, this flexible Pt/CS counter electrode exhibits higher catalytic activity toward Co3+/2+ redox couple regeneration than Pt and CS counter electrodes. The supercatalytic behavior of Pt/CS can essentially be attributed to the low apparent activation energy (E a) of the redox reaction between Co3+ and Co2+. Using the Pt/CS counter electrode, a high power conversion efficiency (PCE) of 9.02% is achieved with a small DSCs (16mm2), and the largescale device (360mm2) generates a PCE of 6.26% under 100mWcm−2 of simulated sunlight illumination.
coredata.dc:title: Large-scale high-efficiency dye-sensitized solar cells based on a Pt/carbon spheres composite catalyst as a flexible counter electrode
